title: Python for Health Data Science

Why Python?
Installing Python
What is an IDE? â†’ Focus on Positron
Version control with Git & GitHub
Coding best practices


Give participants a minute to settle. Mention that today is all setup â€” it may feel slow but itâ€™s the foundation for everything else in the week.

Quick orientation. Emphasise that each session builds on the previous one â€” todayâ€™s setup is needed for everything else.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
What is Programming?

Writing instructions that a computer can execute, step by step.


A program is a recipe: precise, unambiguous, repeatable
Python is a language â€” a way to write those instructions


You donâ€™t need to be a mathematician. You need to be able to think logically.

Analogy: a cooking recipe. If you tell a chef â€œadd some saltâ€, they use judgment. A computer cannot â€” you must be exact. That precision is what programming teaches.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Why Python?


Easy to read
# Find patients over 65
elderly = [p for p in patients
           if p.age > 65]
Almost reads like English.

Huge ecosystem

pandas â€” data tables
numpy â€” numerical computing
scipy â€” statistics
matplotlib / seaborn â€” plots
scikit-learn â€” machine learning
streamlit â€” web apps



Show the code block â€” even a non-programmer can guess what it does. That readability lowers the barrier to entry enormously.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Python in Health Data Science
Real-world uses in medicine and research:

ğŸ¥ Clinical data analysis â€” patient cohort studies, survival analysis
ğŸ§¬ Genomics & bioinformatics â€” sequence analysis, variant calling
ğŸ©» Medical imaging â€” DICOM processing, deep learning diagnostics
ğŸ“Š Public health â€” epidemiological modelling (COVID-19 models were largely Python)
ğŸ“ Reproducible research â€” Quarto notebooks combining code + text


If anyone is sceptical about whether Python is â€œseriousâ€ enough for medicine, mention that Nature, The Lancet, and NEJM have all published studies with Python-based analyses.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Programming Languages: The Landscape








Language
Strengths
Role in health data




ğŸ Python
General purpose, ML/AI, readable
Analysis, models, pipelines, apps


ğŸ“Š R
Statistics, visualisation
Clinical trials, bioinformatics


ğŸ—ƒï¸ SQL
Querying databases
Electronic records, registries


âš¡ Julia
High-performance numerics
Simulations, pharmacokinetics


ğŸ”§ Bash
Automation, scripting
Data pipelines, batch processing









Tip


They complement each other. Many real workflows combine SQL to extract, Python to analyse, and R for statistical reporting.




No need to learn them all. The goal today is Python. But understanding the landscape helps you choose the right tool â€” and understand why Python is increasingly the default for data science in health.

title: Python for Health Data Science
section: The Terminal â€” Your New Best Friend
text:
The Terminal â€” Your New Best Friend
The terminal (Command Prompt / PowerShell on Windows, Terminal on macOS) lets you talk to your computer with text commands.


Open it:

Windows â†’ search â€œCommand Promptâ€ or â€œPowerShellâ€
macOS â†’ search â€œTerminalâ€ (or use Spotlight: âŒ˜ Space)


Essential commands:
# Where am I?
pwd

# List files here
ls        # macOS
dir       # Windows

# Move into a folder
cd my_project


Spend 2 minutes on this. Open it live. Type pwd and ls. The goal is just to demystify it â€” many beginners are afraid of the terminal. Reassure them: you canâ€™t break anything by typing wrong commands (within reason).

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Python Versions

Current stable release: Python 3.x (use 3.11 or 3.12)
Python 2 is dead â€” donâ€™t install it
Version numbers: 3.12.2 â†’ major . minor . patch


# Check if Python is already installed
python --version
# or
python3 --version

Someone in the room may already have Python installed (e.g.Â via Anaconda). Itâ€™s worth checking before installing again.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Installing Python â€” Windows

Go to python.org/downloads
Download the latest Python 3.x installer
Run the installer â€” check â€œAdd Python to PATHâ€ âœ…
Verify in Command Prompt:

python --version






Warning


Always tick â€œAdd Python to PATHâ€ during installation, or nothing will work from the terminal.




Live demo here. Walk slowly through the installer. The PATH checkbox is the single most common mistake beginners make.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Installing Python â€” macOS
Option A â€” Direct (recommended for beginners):

Go to python.org/downloads
Download the macOS installer (.pkg)
Run and follow prompts
Verify in Terminal: python3 --version


Option B â€” Homebrew (package manager, more powerful):
# Install Homebrew first (from brew.sh)
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

# Then install Python
brew install python

Homebrew is worth mentioning for Mac users who want to manage multiple tools. Donâ€™t spend too long on it â€” for todayâ€™s session the direct installer is perfectly fine.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
A Word on Anaconda
Youâ€™ll often see Anaconda (or Miniconda) mentioned in tutorials â€” itâ€™s an alternative Python distribution bundled with data science packages and its own package manager (conda).





Python.org
Anaconda




Install size
Small
Large (~3 GB)


Package manager
pip
conda + pip


Popular in
General / web
Academia / data science











Note


We use plain Python + pip this week. If a colleague sends you a conda command, it works the same way â€” just swap pip install â†’ conda install.




Donâ€™t install Anaconda today. Just mention it so students donâ€™t panic when they see it elsewhere. The key message: itâ€™s not magic, just a different way to get Python and packages.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
What is pip?
pip = Pythonâ€™s package installer
# Install a package
pip install pandas

# Install a specific version
pip install pandas==2.2.0

# List installed packages
pip list

Think of it like an app store for Python libraries.

They wonâ€™t use pip directly today, but theyâ€™ll see it used throughout the week. Just plant the concept.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
What is a Virtual Environment?
A virtual environment isolates packages per project â€” no conflicts between projects.
# Create a virtual environment
python -m venv .venv

# Activate it (macOS/Linux)
source .venv/bin/activate

# Activate it (Windows)
.venv\Scripts\activate

# Install packages inside it
pip install pandas numpy






Tip


Positron (our IDE) manages virtual environments for you automatically.




Donâ€™t dive deep here â€” just mention it exists. Positron makes this transparent. Come back to it if asked.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:

Text Editor
IDE




Edit code
âœ…
âœ…

âŒ

Examples: Notepad, nano = editors Â· VS Code, Positron, PyCharm = IDEs

You can write Python in Notepad. You can also cook on a camping stove. But for daily work, you want a proper kitchen.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
VS Code â€” Quick Overview
Visual Studio Code (by Microsoft) is the worldâ€™s most popular code editor.

Free, open source, cross-platform
Huge extension marketplace
Works for Python, R, JavaScript, â€¦
Not specialised for data science








Note


We mention VS Code because youâ€™ll see it everywhere online. But for data science, weâ€™ll use Positron.




Show VS Code briefly if you have it open. Point out the sidebar, terminal, and extension panel. Then pivot to Positron.

title: Python for Health Data Science
section: Positron â€” The Data Science IDE
text:
Positron â€” The Data Science IDE
Positron is a new IDE built by Posit (creators of RStudio), forked from VS Code.


Why Positron for data science?

Built-in variable explorer
Interactive data viewer (like a spreadsheet)
Plots panel â€” no pop-up windows
First-class Quarto support
Works with Python and R
AI assistant (Positron Data Assistant)





Positron interface




This is the main sell. If students have used RStudio, Positron will feel immediately familiar. If not, highlight the data viewer â€” seeing a table without writing print(df) is a game changer for beginners.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Installing Positron

Go to positron.posit.co
Download for your OS (Windows / macOS)
Install and open
Positron will detect your Python installation automatically


First steps in Positron:

Open a folder as your project
Create a new .py file
Run your first line: print("Hello, health data!")
Observe the Console, Variables, and Plots panels


Live demo. Create a new folder, open it in Positron, create a .py file, type a few lines and run them. Show the variable explorer populating as you assign variables.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Positron â€” Interface Tour




Left
Right




Top
ğŸ“ Explorer (files)
âœï¸ Editor â€” your .py files


Bottom

ğŸ“Š Variables Â· ğŸ“ˆ Plots / Viewer




Point to each panel while running code live. Assign a variable in the editor, run it, show it appear in Variables. Load a CSV and show it in the Viewer.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Your First Python Lines
Open Positron â†’ new file â†’ type these â†’ press Run:
# A greeting
print("Hello, health data!")

# Variables
patient_age = 34
bmi = 22.5
is_diabetic = False

# A simple calculation
height_m = 1.72
weight_kg = 74
bmi = weight_kg / height_m ** 2
print(f"BMI: {bmi:.1f}")

Watch the Variables panel fill up as each line runs. âœ¨

This is the payoff moment for the whole installation section. Keep it light and fun. If someone has an error, use it as a teaching moment â€” reading error messages is a key skill.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
â˜• Break â€” 10 minutes
Back at [time + 10 min]

Good moment to help anyone still stuck on installation before moving to Git.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Why Version Control?

â€œWhich file is the final version?â€


analysis_final.py
analysis_final_v2.py
analysis_final_FINAL.py
analysis_final_FINAL_use_this_one.py  â† ğŸ˜…


Version control solves this:

Every change is tracked with a message
You can go back to any point in history
Multiple people can work on the same project
Nothing is ever truly lost


Every researcher recognises the â€œfinal_FINALâ€ problem. This is the emotional hook â€” version control is the professional solution.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
GitHub.com
GitHub is a cloud platform for hosting Git repositories.

Public repos â€” open source, visible to everyone
Private repos â€” only you (and collaborators) can see them
Great for sharing analysis code with collaborators or reviewers
Journals increasingly require code availability â†’ GitHub is the standard


â†’ Create a free account at github.com

Mention that GitHub is owned by Microsoft. For health data: never put patient data in a GitHub repo â€” only code. Data stays local or in a secure server.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
GitHub Desktop
GitHub Desktop makes Git visual â€” no command line needed.
Install: desktop.github.com

Basic workflow:

Create a new repository (or Clone an existing one)
Edit files in your project
GitHub Desktop shows what changed
Write a short commit message â†’ Commit to main
Push to sync with GitHub.com


Live demo: create a new repo in GitHub Desktop, create a Python file in Positron, go back to GitHub Desktop, show the diff, write a commit message, commit, push. Open github.com to show it live online.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Git Workflow â€” In Practice
Your Computer                     GitHub.com
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€                 â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

 [Edit files]
      â”‚
      â–¼
 [git commit]  â”€â”€â”€â”€ push â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â–º  [Remote repo]
      â”‚                                  â”‚

With GitHub Desktop: all of this is point-and-click.

Reinforce the mental model. â€œCommitâ€ saves locally, â€œpushâ€ sends to the cloud, â€œpullâ€ brings cloud changes back to you.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Why Best Practices Matter
Code is read many more times than it is written.

â€œAlways write code as if the person who will maintain it is a violent psychopath who knows where you live.â€ â€” Martin Golding


More practically: future you will thank present you.

Lighten the mood with the quote, then bring it back to reality. In health research, code may need to be audited, reproduced, or handed over to colleagues.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
PEP 8 â€” Pythonâ€™s Style Guide
PEP 8 is the official Python style guide. Key rules:
# âœ… Good
patient_age = 65
MAX_RETRIES = 3

def calculate_bmi(weight_kg, height_m):
    return weight_kg / height_m ** 2

# âŒ Avoid
PatientAge = 65        # CamelCase for variables
x = 65                 # cryptic names
def calc(w,h): return w/h**2  # no spaces, unclear

The point isnâ€™t memorising PEP 8 â€” Positron and VS Code flag violations automatically. The point is awareness.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Naming Conventions



What
Convention
Example




Variables & functions
snake_case
patient_id, load_data()


Constants
UPPER_SNAKE_CASE
MAX_AGE = 120


Classes
PascalCase
PatientRecord


Private (internal)
_leading_underscore
_raw_data




Rule of thumb: names should explain what something is, not how itâ€™s stored.
# âŒ df2      â†’ what is this?
# âœ… filtered_patients  â†’ clear!

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Comments & Docstrings
# Single-line comment: explain the WHY, not the WHAT

# âŒ Bad: obvious comment
x = x + 1  # add 1 to x

# âœ… Good: explains intent
age += 1  # adjust for 0-indexed age groups in the dataset

def normalise_score(score, max_score):
    """
    Normalise a raw score to a 0â€“1 scale.

    Parameters
    ----------
    score : float
        Raw score value.
    max_score : float
        Maximum possible score.

    Returns
    -------
    float
        Normalised score between 0 and 1.
    """
    return score / max_score

Docstrings are picked up by Positronâ€™s hover documentation and by tools like Sphinx for auto-generating docs. Encourage writing them from day one.

title: Python for Health Data Science
text:
Project Folder Structure
my_project/
â”œâ”€â”€ data/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ raw/          â† original files, never modified
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ processed/    â† cleaned versions
â”œâ”€â”€ notebooks/        â† exploratory .ipynb or .qmd files
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/          â† reusable .py functions
â”œâ”€â”€ outputs/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ figures/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ tables/
â”œâ”€â”€ README.md         â† what is this project?
â””â”€â”€ requirements.txt  â† which packages are needed






Tip


Keep raw/ data read-only. Always work on copies in processed/.




This structure scales from a small homework project to a full research pipeline. The README and requirements.txt are what make a repo usable by others (or by you in 6 months).

This is the â€œexit ticketâ€ â€” check that everyone has the tools ready before they leave. If someone is stuck on installation, this is the moment to help or arrange help during the break.

title: Python para CiÃªncia de Dados em SaÃºde
text:
Worksheet 1 - Fundamentals Practice
The median of a set of numbers is the value separating the higher half from the lower half of a data sample, a population, or a probability distribution. The median of a finite list of numbers is the â€œmiddleâ€ number, when those numbers are listed in order from smallest to greatest.
If the data set has an odd number of observations, the middle one is selected (after arranging in ascending order). For example, the following list of seven numbers,
1, 3, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9
has the median of 6, which is the fourth value.
If the data set has an even number of observations, there is no distinct middle value and the median is usually defined to be the arithmetic mean of the two middle values. For example, this data set of 8 numbers
1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9
has a median value of 4.5, which results from \((4+5)/2\)
Body mass index (BMI) is a value derived from the mass (weight) and height of a person. The BMI is defined as the body mass divided by the square of the body height, and is expressed in units of kg/m2, resulting from mass in kilograms (kg) and height in metres (m).
TASK A (20 minutes)
Create a function calc_median that will calculate the median of a given list of numbers. Use the bubble sort algorithm.
Input: my_list = [13, 0, 12, 3, 2, 17, 8, 1] print(calc_median(my_list))
Output: 5.5
TASK B (10 minutes)
Crate a function compute_bmi(weight_kg, height_cm) that will calculate the BMI of a given weight (kg) and height (cm).
Input: patient_weight = 70.3 patient_height = 181 print(compute_bmi(patient_weight, patient_height))
Output: 21.4584414395165
